Operations on Octet Sequences

In TJS2, octet sequences are pseudo-treated as objects of the Octet class, but the Octet class does not actually exist, and they are not actually objects of an Octet class (however, using the typeof operator on an octet sequence will return "Octet").
However, by treating octet sequences as objects, several methods and properties become available.

Implementation regarding octet sequences is incomplete.

length

The length property returns the length of the octet sequence. Note that it is a property, not a method. However, you cannot assign a value to this property.


Example:
    var oct = <% 11 22 33 %>;
    var n = oct.length;  // 3 is assigned to n
    var n = <% 11 22 33 %>.length; // Similarly, 3 is assigned to this as well

'Numeric' Property

By specifying a number indirectly as a property, you can access the octet at that position.
The result is represented by the numeric value of the octet.
For example, if oct is an expression representing an octet sequence, oct[0] is the numeric value representing the first octet.
An exception occurs if the number points to a position beyond the length of the octet sequence or if it is negative.

You cannot generate assignment expressions.

Example:
    var oct = <% 11 22 33 44 55 %>;
    var c = oct[0];  // 0x11 is assigned to c
    var c = oct[2];  // 0x22 is assigned to c
    oct[3] = 'A'; // An error occurs because assignment expressions cannot be generated
    var c = oct[100]; // An error occurs because the value is out of range
